Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Towards a Computational Infrastructure for Analysis of Sensitive Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
In many applications, e.g., health, education, our ability to realize the full potential of big data to improve decisions and outcomes is currently limited, by the lack of practical frameworks for analysis of sensitive data in a manner that does not violate applicable data access and use policies. This constitutes a significant barrier to the engagement of researchers with expertise in analytics in developing and evaluating advanced methods for analysis of such data, assessing the performance of alternative approaches, or ensuring the reproducibility of results. Against this background, this high-risk and potentially high-impact research project aims to explore a framework and a software infrastructure for data access and use policy (DAUP) compliant analysis of sensitive data.

The project aims to develop a novel framework for data access and use policy (DAUP) compliant analysis of sensitive data. The framework will support (i) Querying and retrieval of information from the data store that are permitted by the user or project specific DAUP. Such information could include the schema of the data store, metadata that specify the variables, and their domains and ranges, etc.; (ii) Execution of system or user-supplied implementations of algorithms for construct predictive or causal models or visualizations from the data in the data store; (iii) Evaluation of the predictive performance of the resulting models on benchmark data or user-provided data; (iv) Deployment of the validated models in the form of web servers that provide predictions or visualizations over user-submitted data or over results of user-defined queries against the data store; and (v) Publication of reusable analytics workflows. This exploratory project seeks to test the feasibility of the framework using predictive and causal modeling of data from an online health community as a test case. A major outcome of this project is the open source software infrastructure for facilitating analysis and visualization of sensitive data. This research will: (i) fill a major gap in infrastructure for predictive modeling from sensitive data; (ii) significantly lower the barrier to the entry of researchers with deep expertise in analytics to domains (e.g., health, education) that involve sensitive data; (iii) improve the accuracy of assessment of the state-of-the-art in predictive and causal modeling in such domains by facilitating rigorous comparison of algorithms; and (iv) facilitate, reproducible analysis of sensitive data.

This research will (i) yield a prototype open source software infrastructure to support analysis and visualization of sensitive data; (ii) Accelerate data-driven advances in domains that involve sensitive data e.g., health, education through broad engagement of talent in developing better algorithms; and (iii) Support incorporation of hands-on experience with such applications into Data Sciences education through hackathons and competitions organized around specific sensitive data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background: Exponential increase in our ability to acquire, store, and analyze data across all areas of human endeavor offer unprecedented opportunities for improving the human condition, e.g., through data-driven, evidence-based policies and interventions. However, in critical domains such as healthcare, education, finance, intelligence, network security and malware analytics, the benefits of data analytics have to be weighed against the potential harm to individuals through unintended disclosure of sensitive information. Hence, there is an urgent need for digital infrastructure and tools for data access and use policy (DAUP) compliant data analytics, i.e., analyses of sensitive data in a manner that does not violate applicable data access and use policies. 

Intellectual Merit: This exploratory research project brought together a team of researchers with complementary expertise in artificial intelligence, data sciences, machine learning, and privacy and security to develop the critical technologies for DAUP compliant data analytics. The team worked with diverse stakeholders (researchers, institutional leaders, security and privacy experts, data ethicists) to identify and articulate the technical and socio-technical (organizational, policy, and ethical) considerations that must inform the design of DAUP-compliant data analytics infrastructure. The team developed a critical enabling technology for DAUP-compliant analytics, namely, a novel fine-grained access control (FGAC) mechanism for controlling the access to not only data to be analyzed, but also,  the analyses modules to be used, and the results of analyses. 

Broader Impacts: As an important use case of DAUP-compliant data analytics, team designed a Digital Collaboratory for Precision Health Research (DCPHR). DCPHR utilizes the FGAC mechanism mentioned above to support Hippocratic DAUP-compliant data analytics workflows, i.e., modular, composable, customizable, extensible, auditable, and sharable data analytics pipelines. DCPHR supports predictive and causal modeling from diverse sources of health data, including data derived from electronic health records, behavioral measurements, socio-demographic and environmental records. In collaboration with clinical and public health researchers, the team launched several proof-of-concept studies, e.g., those aimed at elucidating the socio-demographic and other contextual variables driving the ?diseases of despair? in rural Pennsylvania, and more broadly, across the nation; and data-driven optimization biomarkers for early stage detection of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder, peripheral vascular disease, renal failure, severe chronic liver disease, dementia, various types of cancer, diabetes, and obesity. The team established a data governance structure (with representation from institutional leadership, researchers, infrastructure experts, data scientists, security and privacy experts, data ethicists) to oversee DCPHR. Because the ability to gain useful insights from sensitive or restricted data could benefit many applications, e.g., finance, intelligence analysis, network security and malware analytics, etc., they could all benefit from similar DAUP-compliant data analytics infrastructure. The project has provided enhanced research-based training opportunities to graduate (4 PhD, 1 MS), undergraduate, and post-doctoral students, especially as they relate to the technical, socio-technical (organizational, policy, and ethical) considerations that shape real-world applications of data sciences. Some of the research results have informed the design of course modules and course projects in undergraduate and graduate Data Sciences curricula at Penn State. Results of this research, including open source software, peer-reviewed publications, are being made available to the research community. Additional information about the project is being made available through the website of the Penn State Artificial Intelligence Research Laboratory (http://ailab.ist.psu.edu).
